questions.title: Gauss's Law - Electric Field
questions.question_text: Gauss's law for electricity states that the electric flux through any closed surface is proportional to the enclosed charge: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E} = \frac{ρ}{ε_0}$$ where E⃗ is the electric field, ρ is charge density, and ε₀ = 8.854×10⁻¹²F/m. For a point charge Q = 10nC, find the electric field at distance r = 5cm.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using $$E = \frac{1}{4πε_0} \frac{Q}{r^2}$$ with Q = 10×10⁻⁹C and r = 0.05m gives E = 3.6×10⁴V/m

questions.title: Gauss's Law - Magnetic Field
questions.question_text: Gauss's law for magnetism states that magnetic field lines form closed loops with no magnetic monopoles: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ This can also be written in integral form as $$\oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{A} = 0$$ What does this imply about magnetic field lines?
choices: Magnetic field lines begin at north poles and end at south poles
Magnetic field lines are always closed loops with no beginning or end
The magnetic flux ΦB through any surface equals μ₀I
questions.correct_answer: Magnetic field lines are always closed loops with no beginning or end
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ means no magnetic monopoles exist - field lines must form closed loops
questions.feedback_incorrect: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ is the mathematical statement that magnetic field lines have no sources or sinks

questions.title: Faraday's Law - Complex Notation
questions.question_text: Faraday's law describes electromagnetic induction: $$\nabla \times \mathbf{E} = -\frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}$$ For a circular loop of radius r = 2cm in a time-varying magnetic field $$\mathbf{B}(t) = B_0 \cos(ωt) \hat{z}$$ where B₀ = 0.5T and ω = 2π×60rad/s, calculate the induced EMF magnitude |ℰ| = |dΦB/dt|.
questions.feedback_correct: Excellent! $$Φ_B = B_0 π r^2 \cos(ωt)$$, so $$|ℰ| = \left|\frac{dΦ_B}{dt}\right| = B_0 π r^2 ω = 0.5 × π × (0.02)^2 × 377 = 0.047\text{V}$$

questions.title: Ampère-Maxwell Law - Full Complexity
questions.question_text: The Ampère-Maxwell law (4th Maxwell equation) includes both conduction and displacement currents: $$\nabla \times \mathbf{B} = μ_0 \mathbf{J} + μ_0 ε_0 \frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$ The displacement current density is $$\mathbf{J}_D = ε_0 \frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$. For a parallel-plate capacitor with A = 1cm², d = 1mm, charging at dV/dt = 10⁶V/s, find |JD|.
questions.feedback_correct: Perfect! $$E = V/d$$, so $$\frac{dE}{dt} = \frac{1}{d}\frac{dV}{dt}$$, giving $$|\mathbf{J}_D| = ε_0 \frac{10^6}{10^{-3}} = 8.854 \times 10^{-3}\text{ A/m²}$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: For a parallel plate capacitor: $$\mathbf{E} = \frac{V}{d}\hat{z}$$, so $$\frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t} = \frac{1}{d}\frac{dV}{dt}\hat{z}$$

questions.title: Maxwell Equations - Vector Identities
questions.question_text:
From Maxwell's equations in vacuum: $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{E} = 0$$, $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$, $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{E} = - rac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}$$, $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{B} = μ_0 ε_0  rac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$. Taking the divergence of the 4th equation and using $$
abla \cdot (
abla 	imes \mathbf{B}) = 0$$, we can prove that $$ rac{\partial}{\partial t}(
abla \cdot \mathbf{E}) = 0$$, which is consistent with the 1st equation.
questions.feedback_correct:
True! Taking $$
abla \cdot$$ of $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{B} = μ_0 ε_0  rac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$ gives $$0 = μ_0 ε_0  rac{\partial}{\partial t}(
abla \cdot \mathbf{E})$$, so $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{E}$$ is constant (and equals 0 in vacuum)
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the vector identity $$\nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{V}) = 0$$ for any vector field $$\mathbf{V}$$

questions.title: Wave Equation from Maxwell
questions.question_text: In vacuum, Maxwell's equations lead to the wave equation: $$\nabla^2 \mathbf{E} - μ_0 ε_0 \frac{\partial^2 \mathbf{E}}{\partial t^2} = 0$$ The speed of electromagnetic waves is $$c = \frac{1}{\sqrt{μ_0 ε_0}}$$. Given μ₀ = 4π×10⁻⁷H/m and ε₀ = 8.854×10⁻¹²F/m, calculate c in m/s (×10⁸).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Calculate $$\sqrt{μ_0 ε_0} = \sqrt{4π \times 10^{-7} \times 8.854 \times 10^{-12}}$$ first, then take reciprocal

questions.title: Boundary Conditions - Complex Subscripts
questions.question_text: At the boundary between two media, Maxwell's equations impose boundary conditions. For the tangential components: $$\mathbf{n} \times (\mathbf{E}_2 - \mathbf{E}_1) = 0$$ and $$\mathbf{n} \times (\mathbf{B}_2 - \mathbf{B}_1) = μ_0 \mathbf{K}$$ where n̂ is the surface normal and K⃗ is surface current density. For a perfect conductor (σ → ∞), what are the boundary conditions?
choices: E⃗∥ = 0, B⃗∥ = μ₀K⃗ at the surface
E⃗ = 0 inside, B⃗⊥ = μ₀σJ⃗ at surface
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For perfect conductors: $$\mathbf{E}_{tangential} = 0$$ (no tangential E-field), $$\mathbf{B}_{tangential} = μ_0 \mathbf{K}$$ (surface currents)
questions.feedback_incorrect: In perfect conductors: E⃗ = 0 inside, so tangential E must be zero at surface. Surface currents create tangential B-field

questions.title: Poynting Vector - Energy Flow
questions.question_text: The Poynting vector describes electromagnetic energy flow: $$\mathbf{S} = \frac{1}{μ_0} \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}$$ For a plane wave $$\mathbf{E} = E_0 \cos(kz - ωt) \hat{x}$$ and $$\mathbf{B} = \frac{E_0}{c} \cos(kz - ωt) \hat{y}$$, the time-averaged intensity is $$\langle S \rangle = \frac{1}{2μ_0 c} E_0^2$$. If E₀ = 100V/m, find ⟨S⟩ in W/m².
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use $$\langle S \rangle = \frac{E_0^2}{2μ_0 c}$$ where c = 3×10⁸m/s and μ₀ = 4π×10⁻⁷H/m

questions.title: Stress Test - All Notation Types
questions.question_text: Maxwell stress tensor components in vacuum: $$T_{ij} = ε_0 \left(E_i E_j - \frac{1}{2}δ_{ij} E^2\right) + \frac{1}{μ_0}\left(B_i B_j - \frac{1}{2}δ_{ij} B^2\right)$$ For uniform fields E⃗ = E₀ẑ and B⃗ = B₀x̂, calculate T₃₃ (the zz-component).
questions.feedback_correct: Excellent! Since E⃗ = E₀ẑ: E₃ = E₀, E² = E₀². Since B⃗ = B₀x̂: B₃ = 0, B² = B₀². So $$T_{33} = ε_0(0 - E_0^2/2) + \frac{1}{μ_0}(0 - B_0^2/2)$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Substitute E₃ = E₀, E² = E₀², B₃ = 0, B² = B₀² into the tensor formula
